title: Getting Started with Next.js
description: A beginner's guide to setting up your first Next.js application.
content:
## Introduction

Next.js is a popular React framework for building server-side rendered and static websites. This guide will walk you through the initial setup.

### Prerequisites

*   Node.js installed
*   Basic understanding of React

### Steps

1.  Create a new Next.js app:
    ```bash
    npx create-next-app@latest my-next-app
    ```
2.  Navigate into your project directory:
    ```bash
    cd my-next-app
    ```
3.  Start the development server:
    ```bash
    npm run dev
    ```

Your app should now be running on `http://localhost:3000`.

Happy coding!

title: hello
content:
15 Blogs We Love To Read
A Cup of Jo
If you read blogs, you probably read A Cup of Jo. As the saying goes ‚Äúcome for the blog, stay for the comments‚Äù and that‚Äôs what everyone who reads Cup of Jo does. Some of our favorite articles ever have been from A Cup of Jo on topics ranging from relationships to parenting to travel. A Cup of Jo is one of our favorite blogs for weekly links and reads, tear jerkers, funny stories and practical tips for every part of life.

Made by Carli
Fellow Rhode Islander Carli of Made by Carli is a DIY pro. Carli creates beautiful and inviting spaces and shares the process on her blog and Instagram. She‚Äôs currently working her way through her 1940s colonial fixer upper and the progress is so fun to watch. Check out what she‚Äôs done in the kitchen with a range hood DIY, and a gorgeous glass cabinet. She is great at taking you step by step through her process and her projects are easy to follow. If you love home renos and DIY projects definitely check out Made by Carli.

The Well Co
The Well Co by our friend Meg, based on Cape Cod, is a blog with tons of support and guidance for mothers. Meg provides a place for new and expecting moms to come together and feel less alone. Meg is a registered dietician nutritionist who created The Well Co to support mothers with everything from recipes to courses on nursing, pregnancy supplements and baby led weaning guides.

The Stripe
The Stripe is one of our favorite lifestyle blogs to read. Jess met Grace Atwood many years ago on a press trip, and has been following her blog and career ever since. We love Grace‚Äôs book recommendations along with her honest and incredibly thorough beauty product reviews. She also has great style finds and shares inspiring home decor, recipes and more. Don‚Äôt just take it from us though, Grace has a very loyal following with a large newsletter subscriber base and a huge Facebook Group!

Fresh Exchange
If you love gardening and cooking Fresh Exchange is a great follow. For 12 years, Megan Gilger has been using Fresh Exchange to help her readers navigate the seasons from garden to kitchen. Megan has a big focus on community which she fosters through her blog and online community platform where members can share their experiences and learn from Megan in the garden. You can find everything from recipes to gardening tips and DIY projects on her blog.

An Indigo Day
Atlanta based blogger Jessica Camerata is the voice behind lifestyle blog An Indigo Day. She shares a ton of style content with lots of tips including her recent very popular series on updating your Millennial style. Jess also shares travel guides, life advice, beauty and hair content, home decor, and more. For those looking to get into the business of blogging, Jess also runs The Blog Societies.

Alicia Tenise
Alicia is an LA-based blogger (and now author), who covers everything from travel to fashion to wine. If you‚Äôre looking to plan your next trip she has great travel recommendations and she is exceptionally knowledgeable on all things wine having recently gone through WSET Certification. Don‚Äôt miss her wine and winery recommendations.

JoJoTastic
Based in the Pacific Northwest, Joanna is a former textile designer turned blogger. She shares amazing DIY projects, styling tips, and lots of reviews of underwear for her popular series, The Underwear Thesis. Joanna has a ton of interior content from her tiny home in Seattle and her now log cabin in the mountains.

This Time Tomorrow
Come here for travel, history, fashion, architecture and stay for the gorgeous photography. This Time Tomorrow is Krystal Bick‚Äôs passion project that verges Parisian yesteryear with current day NYC living. Krystal shares her love of life‚Äôs small pleasures in order to help her readers ‚Äúromanticize the big and small details of (their) own life that make it unique, that make it sing.‚Äù We loved her essay on The Death of Stills and Stillness.

Lindsay Silberman
Lindsay Silberman is a former magazine editor turned blogger and founder of Hotel Lobby Candle. On her blog, Lindsay shares luxur

title: 15 Blogs We Love To Read
description: Blogs are back! But were they ever really gone? For those of us who‚Äôve always loved and read blogs, no, but we‚Äôve noticed a recent focus on ‚Äúgoing back to blogging‚Äù with more bloggers focusing on their own sites and more readers enjoying the content.

title: how to change cmd color
description: In this about how we change the change of terminal or cmd in windows using 1 step
content:
How to change color in windows

Method 1: Temporary Change (Current Session Only)

  1. Open CMD: Press Win + S, type cmd, and press Enter to open the Command Prompt.

  2. Check Color Codes: Type color /? and press Enter to see the list of available colors. The codes are:

  3. Change Color: Type color XY (replace X with the background color code and Y with the text color code). For example, color 1F sets a blue background with bright white text. Press Enter.

Verify: The CMD window‚Äôs colors should change immediately. This change lasts only for the current session; closing CMD reverts to default colors.

Method 2: Permanent Change (All Future Sessions)

  1. Open CMD: Press Win + S type cmd, and press Enter to open the Command Prompt.

  2. Access Properties: Right-click the title bar of the CMD window (where it says "Command Prompt") and select "Properties."

  3. Go to Colors Tab: In the Properties window, click the "Colors" tab.

  4. Apply Changes: Click "OK" to save. This applies the colors to all future CMD sessions launched from the same shortcut.

title: Consistency
description: Want to be more consistent towards my tasks its as good as  practice makes a man perfect.
content:
What‚Äôs one small improvement you can make in your life?

On this note I‚Äôll be incorporating this small but crucial change into my ongoing life.

It has to be Aunt June. June was born in 1932 in London‚Äôs East End. Extended family lived all around her. She adored her two older brothers and followed them around everywhere, much to their annoyance. She grew up not intellectually gifted, but gifted in other ways; she was an artist, an excellent seamstress (she often made my clothes), and she knew how to bring out the best in people. She was a housewife/homemaker, and this was the career she was born to do. June‚Äôs house was a happy one; nobody every shouted or argued, like my mother and I did.

Every year Mum and Dad would send me to stay with Aunt June, Uncle Stan, and their two daughters for a week during the school summer holidays. June would sit with me and make glitter pictures, something my own mother never did as she was always at work. My cousins and I would rake over the dressing-up box in the shed and find clothes and high heeled shoes to parade about in, and June would take us out during the day to the seaside or the funfair (they lived only a few miles from the coast). I would hold her hand as we walked along, and she would squeeze my fingers and smile down at me. As a kid I wished I could live with June and Stan permanently.

As I grew older and had my own family, June and I would still ring each other at least once a week. Sam could always tell when June had rung, because I‚Äôd be laughing throughout the telephone conversation. When she was dying, she asked to see me one more time. I sat with her two weeks before she died and held her hand. I gave her fingers a squeeze, and she did the same to mine just like she did when I was a kid. We didn‚Äôt say much; we didn‚Äôt need to.

June died aged 79 in 2012, but I still think about her every day. Her funeral was the largest one I had ever seen. She was a people person; no degrees, no highbrow career as such, but just full of love for friends, neighbours and family.

title: Top 10 Indian Blogs to Read from Popular Indian Bloggers [2025 Special Edition]
description: Are you looking for the best Indian blogs to read? Curious to know the top bloggers from India? Your search ends here.
content:
On this page, you‚Äôll discover the top Indian blogs to follow in 2025. There are only two ways to succeed in blogging: reading and implementing.

If you‚Äôre not a regular reader of blogs and don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs going on around your niche, you can never create a successful blog that makes money.

Forget endless searching ‚Äì we‚Äôve handpicked a list of the BEST Indian blogs waiting to be explored. From tech gurus to culinary masters, there‚Äôs something for everyone. Let‚Äôs get started!

This list is a curated collection of some of the best blogs in India to read which keeps you inspired to blog better üôÇ

Best Indian Bloggers To Follow In 2025 (Popular Blogs)

1. Labnol.org, Amit Agarwal

There‚Äôs a reason we put Labnol #1 in this list of top blogs in India. The reason is the guy behind it: Amit Agarwal.

This famous blog was started by Amit Agarwal with a vision to spread the culture of blogging in India. Amit quit his job to become the first professional blogger from India.

Amit holds a degree from IIT, one of the most prestigious engineering institutions in India. He is also listed in the Adsense success story by Google. On this blog, Amit mostly covers tech-related topics, including How-to guides and solutions to tech issues.

Labnol is undoubtedly the best blogs in India where you can find technology simplified for you.

2. YourStory.com, Shardha SharmaAre you looking for inspiration and guidance in the startup world? Look no further than Yourstory, a leading Indian platform that mostly covers the journeys of successful entrepreneurs.

Founded by Shardha Sharma, YourStory showcases not only the latest business trends and startup stories but also emphasizes the power of women in leadership.

In a short time, YourStory has established itself as a valuable resource for the Indian startups, providing a mix of success stories, practical business advice, and more.
